clinical_study.brief_title: Sweat Duct Imaging in Mother/Newborn Dyads
clinical_study.official_title: Sweat Duct Imaging in Mother/Newborn Dyads

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate sweat duct number on the plantar surface of newborn infants using a non-invasive confocal microscopy device.

detailed_description.textblock: In this exploratory study, the investigators propose to evaluate sweat duct number on the plantar surface of newborn infants using a non-invasive confocal microscopy device (Lucid VivascopeÂ®). This approach has the potential to be valuable in repeated sweat endpoint assessments, as the device was selected based on its ease of use, the low risk to patients of all ages, and its ability to generate quantitative data.

primary_outcome.measure: Demonstrate the use of a confocal microscope to quantify sweat ducts on the plantar surface of healthy, term newborns
primary_outcome.description: To demonstrate the ease of use of a non-invasive confocal imaging device in the evaluation and measurement of sweat ducts on the plantar surface of healthy, term newborns. These measurements will be used as comparison data in subsequent trials involving those affected by X-Linked Hypohidrotic Ectodermal Dysplasia.

primary_outcome.measure: To assess the sweat duct density (i.e. the number of sweat ducts) in a 6 x 6 mm area on the plantar surface of healthy, term newborns, males and females, and the palmar surface of their mothers
primary_outcome.description: These measurements will be used as comparison data in subsequent trials involving those affected by X-Linked Hypohidrotic Ectodermal Dysplasia.

study_pop.textblock: The study will enroll up to twenty healthy term newborns and their mothers in the Assessment Nursery at Barnes-Jewish Hospital.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy term newborns (37-42 weeks gestation at delivery) in the Assessment Nursery at Barnes-Jewish Hospital, St. Louis, MO
- Mother of a healthy term newborn who is enrolled in this study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Congenital abnormalities affecting skin, nails, or hair in the newborn infant
- Family history of a sweating disorder
